Conflict of Interest (Duty of Loyalty) between old college roomate and his partner. 
Duty of Competence - "Alex is a recently-licensed attorney with a solo law practice." 
Reasonableness of the Fee's
Fee Splitting and Fee Sharing. 
Unauthorized Practice of Law - Dale is getting paid a lawyer's fee for paralegal work, it's not illegal to hire a disbarred attorney but can't be disguised as a paralegal by making $250 an hour.

Duty of Competence - "Patty contacted Tom, a real estate attorney" 
Duty of Confidentiality - Attorney referred to another attorney without consulting client first. 
Duty to Communicate - Attorney failed to tell client that he was going to refer his case. 
Fee Sharing - Referral to another client. 
Recommending a Lawyer 's Services - "the $200 gift certificate" 
Paying A Witness to Testify - â€œLook, if you will testify truthfully about what you saw, Iâ€™ll put you up in a hotel until you can get back on your feet.â€

Question 1, "serve the summons" brings up the issue of Proper Service.1A - Service on individuals 1B - Service on Corporations
 
Question 2 - Personal Jurisdiction
2A - On a person, consent, domicile, or residency. Valery resides in San Francisco, the forum state, so yes on Valerie as to PJ. 2B - On a corp, PPB (nerve center) or any state incorporated. Meyer did not consent and appears to only be a citizen of Germany. We have very little information on the minimum contacts or substantial business prong, so likely outcome is no PJ on Meyer Corp. 


Question 3. Proper Venue
Valerie's residency is in San Fran where the injury occurred while Meyere is resident in Germany. Venue is not proper in San Diego. 
 

Question 4 - Removal (which leads to SMJ) 
(All D's must agree, must be within 30 days, will not be granted if any D is a citizen of forum state, and must have been able to P could have originally brought the case in Federal Court). SMJ Federal Question - N/A Diversity - No party same domicile - Amount in Controversy over 75K - Supplemental JDX 
 

SO, since the case could NOT have been brought in Fed Court because No Fed Q, No amount qualifies for amount-in-controversy, Valerie is a citizen of CA and we don't know anything else concretely, the case CAN NOT BE removed to Federal Court.

So here's a quick tip: Don't force it. This was my lowest scoring essay on the exam and it's because BA had been predicted. PR is one of the subjects that's always on the bar exam so just KNOW IT. This year, BA had been predicted for the essay so I was hyper vigilant in trying to spot a BA crossover in every exam. As it turns out, that was later in Question 5 and I spent a lot of time talking about an issue that wasn't there (Principal and Agency). If I had the chance to go back, I would have practiced issue spotting on every PR exam and not been lured into discussing irrelevant topics.   I blew it and got a 50, have a look.   

EXAM LINK

The call of the question give us the "Answer to California Law" so we know it's Wills or CP. Going back to the opening paragraph we immediately spot "Trusts."


Churches Arguments Supporting It's Claim To the Trust.
Creation of Trust
The first paragraph rattles off a lot of informational facts leading us to believe that a Creation of Trust is to be discussed. Our neumonic for this is SIP-D-ATVğŸï¸, so in this case we have: Wilma as Settlor, Intent to create a trust, the Property of 1 million, Delivery as 1 million was put into the trust, Ascertainable Bennys (in this case the Church, a charitable organization), Trustee (if no trustee is named a court will appoint one), and a Valid Purpose. In order for a trust to qualify as charitable, the trust needs to benefit the public and charitable purposes furthering health, religion, and / or education. On these facts, Wilma created a valid trust with Church as a beneficiary.


Termination of Trust
Charitable trusts must be perpetual and can terminate in one of three ways: (1) expiration of trust term (2) trust revoked by Settlor, Benny, or Trustee (in CA Trustee can revoke only if principal is not > 40k) or (3) trust purpose fulfilled. Here, Wilma created a charitable trust without mentioning any (1) expiration and there is (2) no facts that state Wilma (Settlor) revoked the trust in life or death. So Sis, with the only remaining way to terminate the trust being that the purpose would be fulfilled, won't be able to since fulfillment has not been reached.


Sis and Dora's Arguments to their Respective Claims
Challenging the Validity of the Will
A valid will requires (1) testator with capacity (2) intent and (3) valid formalities.
Here, "Sis paid attention to Wilma" and the fact that Wilma "reluctantly" left her entire estate doesn't isn't enough to show undue influence. Secondly, Wilma was the one who created the will satisfying the requirement of testamentary intent. The facts show Wilma had capacity so that isn't at issue. Finally, a gift to a sister is not an unnatural bequest, indicated by Wilmas later note that Wilma was pleased with the bequest.
Conclusion is that Sid did not exercise an undue influence over a valid will and that not including the Church trust, Sis should be entitled to the entire estate.



Dora (the explorer)'s Challenge To Wilma's will.
When challenging a will, the burden of proving Undue Influence (SOUP) rests on the person trying to contest the will. There are three rules that apply in this case, 1) if issue are alive at creation of a will but omitted they have no right to inherit, 2) if decedent fails to provide in will for child born after the wills execution, the child CAN receive share of descendants estate, and 3) CA allows a "discretionary" allowance to adult child who are dependent on decedent.


Here, Dora hasn't spoken to Wilma in 20 years, Dora can't prove Undue Influence to tkae by intestacy and no facts show that Dora was dependent on Wilma when she was alive. I mean, 20 years and no call? So in conclusion, Dora does not have a valid challenge to the will.

1a) The Necklace
Source = Henrys inheritance
Presumption = Inheritance while married is spouse;s SP.
Action = **Transmutations **âœ (No signed writing containing language change in ownership signed by spouse whose interest affected).
Exception for Gifts if they are not of substantial value and personal in nature.
Disposition = Husband will argue 25,000 was substantial in nature since they had no money when they got married and wife will argue it was a necklace meant for her as a gift for the holidays. Courts could go either way but the $25,000 seems pretty substantial.


1b) The settlement proceeds
Source= Proceeds from Wendys accident while married.
Presumption = Settlement proceeds while married are presumed to be CP.
Action - At divorce, courts will usually award the injured spouse the proceeds but don't have to.
Disposition - Husband does not likely have an interest.


1c) Stock option profits
Source - Stock options granted while married and exercise after marriage.
Presumption - End of the Marriage ğŸ’”
Action - Number of years married = 3, length of marriage = 4. 3/4 = 75% = 60,000.
Disposition - Divided by 2 = 30,000 for Henry leaving 50k for Wife.


2) Reimbursement of community for child support payments.
Source = Debts incurred BEFORE marriage ğŸ„
Presumption - Community liable to the extent Hank had SP.
Action - Hank inherited SP during the marriage, so cummunity should be reimbursed.
Disposition - Hanks $300 a month income from his inheritance lasted 2 years so CP should be reimbursed $7,200.

The Eleventh Amendment
Standing ğŸ§**
Individual standing exists when:
---P personally suffered an injury in fact (injured or injury is imminent)
---There is causation; AND
---The injury is redressable by court order.


Both suits against State X are barred.

Disposition - Depending on if the court finds an injustice would be carried out, Harry should be entitled to these funds.

Entrapment
The defense of entrapment requires a defendant to show (i) inducement and (ii) a lack of predisposition. Inducement occurs when a criminal design originates with the police. A lack of predisposition occurs when the defendant was not otherwise intending to commit the crime, but only did so because the police applied pressure or some sort of other unfair deceit.

The questions give away these issues but the first facts in the first paragraph is where most of the analysis comes into play. There are two main facts in the first sentence about Pam that give way to some good discussion. Pam's domicile is a key issue and she 1) took an indefinite leave of absence from her job and 2) sublet her apartment to go care for her mother. 

Domicile is defined as the 1) physically present in the state with 2) the intent to permanently remain. This definition also gets used in Community Property essays so it should be a key one to remember. You could argue that if Pam had the intent to permanently remain she would have just quit her job rather than taken a leave of absence. The examiners try to muddy the issue by adding the word "indefinite" but that description still doesn't get you to "permanently remain." 

The second fact, is that she sublet her apartment. If you've practiced any real property exams you'll know that someone sublets their apartment when they transfer all or a portion of the premises for less than the entire term of the lease. Compare to an assignment when they transfer all of what they have. This subtle difference could be discussed as showing an intent to return by the nature of her leaving at least some of her living arrangements in tact in whatever state she left. The rest of the issues are pretty black letter, here's a quick breakdown.

Pay attention to when the bar examiners use the word "indefinite." In one year, an "indefinite leave of absence" was implied to mean the individual did not have the intention to permanently remain. However, in this essay, moving to a state for heart surgery seems to imply that they reside in this state. Job? No. Surgery? Perhaps. (for domicile purposes). 

1. Lack of Personal JDX as to Doctor
No consent, presence (tagged), and Dr was not domiciled in the state where case was filed. (State B) Minimum Contacts? Foreseeable (relatedness and fairness) Dr did not have minimum contacts with State B. Proper. 

2. Lack of Personal JDX as to Valvco
No consent, presence, domicile (PPB or Inc State). Minimum Contacts? (Valvco designed heart valve in State B) - Relatedness? Valco designed the valve in State B and their negligence is what led to this dispute - Fairness? Patient has moved to State B for this surgery, Valvco has employees (or at least the ones who design) living in the state, and state would want to see this resolved. Proper. 

3. Motion for Remand
Which is asking about SMJ Federal Question? N/A Diversity JDX - Domcile? Patient in B (or you could argue A but either way) and Corp in C & D, - Amount in Controversy? $100k, good to go. Removal was proper and Fed Court properly denied the remand back down to state court.

(1) The Free Exercise Clause 
The Free Exercise Clause states that Government may not prohibit the free exercise of any religion.
Sincerely Held Religious Beliefs
ğŸ”´ Strict Scrutiny N,C,LR


(2) the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution.
The Establishment Clause prohibits government from preferring one religion over another or establishing a religion. This clause is typically subjected to the Lemon Test which has three prongs that the law must have (1) a secular purpose, (2) must not advance nor inhibit religion and (3) may not create an excessive entanglement with government.

Reading the call of the question we see distribution of trusts and estate along with "Answer to California law." Anytime there is a requirement to answer to CA law we know community property or wills, this one appears to be straight wills and trusts, and it is.

 


A resulting trust arises when an express trust fails. A settlor, one who creates a trust, transfers his property to a trustee, one appointed, or required by law, to execute a trust, to hold in trust for a beneficiary, one who profits from the act of another. If, without the settlor's knowledge, the beneficiary died before the trust was created, the express trust would fail for want of a beneficiary. The trustee holds the property in resulting trust for the settlor. What gives this essay a twist is that the settlor is also the beneficiary, so if the trust was valid (your first issue) and the beneficiary is dead (Hal), then it would be presumed that Hal's intent would be for the money to go back to himself.

(Issue) Is Tedâ€™s original will valid? Requirements

(Issue) Is the handwritten codicil valid? Holographic Wills

(Issue) What does Bertha receive under Tedâ€™s Will? Devises
Bertha gets the $300,000 of the total $600,000 share of the house (so all of it. BUT, if the will was invalid, then intestate succession provides that the surviving spouse also gets 1/2 of the decedents SP if survived by only one child, so if that was the case then Bertha would get $150k in addition to the $300k house.

(Issue)What does Sam receive under Tedâ€™s will? Valid, then Sam takes the 10k, if invalid, then Sam takes nothing.

(Issue) What does Dot receive under Tedâ€™s will? Dot was an interested witness so it is presumed she procured the 10k by undue influence but Dot would argue the gift is valid because Ted republished the will without revoking her gift so it could go either way.

 


(Issue) What does Cindy receive under Tedâ€™s Will? Depending on how Dot's outcome, Cindy would either receive $280k or $290k.

This is an essay where it pays to read the call of the question first, that way you would immediately know it's a Civ Pro essay. If you don't start by reading the call of the questions, you can begin to think this is a Contract, Remedies, Real Property, or Crossover. After reading all 5 questions, you know you are only in Civ Pro land.


1. Joinder of Claims, yes allowed (FRCP 18)


2. Sufficient Pleadings, No, not sufficiently pled (FRCP 9(b))


3. SMJ - Fed Q? No. Diversity? Yes. Supplemental? Not needed since SMJ is achieved under Diversity due to the amount in controversy exceeded $75k and citizenship diversity.


4. Erie Doctrine - Yes, federal court can apply CA law to breach-of-contract claim


5. Right to Jury Trial - Money damages are guaranteed right to jury per 7th amendment, equitable actions are not triable by jury as a matter of right. When BOTH are sought, right to jury applies of the fact underlying the legal claim, so in this case "Buyer claimed fraud as to the painting" for money damages so a jury trial would be OK for the fraud claim but not for the specific performance claim.

1. Valid Contract Under UCC? âŒ

  • Rule: UCC governs goods sales; requirements contracts need good faith
  • Analysis: No valid requirements contract - Berelli can reject for ANY reason (illusory promise)
  • Result: Contract likely invalid

2. Unconscionability Defense? âœ…

  • Procedural: Grower had no choice - standard form contract, told objections "ineffective"
  • Substantive: Berelli can reject for any reason + banned excess sales to others
  • Result: Strong unconscionability defense for Grower

3. Anticipatory Repudiation? âœ…

  • Rule: Clear intent not to perform = breach
  • Analysis: August 15 - Grower explicitly said won't perform
  • Result: Clear anticipatory breach

4. Replevin Available? âœ…

  • Requirements:
    • Goods identified âœ“
    • Can't get cover âœ“ (only got 10/40 tons needed)
    • At double price âœ“ ($200 vs $100)
  • Result: Replevin likely available

5. Specific Performance? ğŸ¤”

  • Pros: Unique goods (Tabor tomatoes), definite terms, only got 25% of needs
  • Cons: Unconscionability defense
  • Result: Available only if contract enforceable

6. Impossibility Defense? âŒ

  • Still expecting 65 tons despite poor season
  • Result: No excuse

7. Damages? ğŸ’°

  • Expectation damages: (40 tons Ã— $200) - (40 tons Ã— $100) = $4,000
  • Grower's defenses: None viable - damages calculable, foreseeable, Berelli tried to mitigate
  • Result: Berelli likely recovers $4,000

Bottom Line: Contract probably unconscionable, but if enforceable, Berelli has strong remedies available ğŸ“Š
